name: Axiom Unique Factorization Formalization
description: The mathematical formalization of the Unique Factorization Axiom, expressing how non-zero non-unit elements can be uniquely represented as products of primes.
text:
In a unique factorization domain (UFD) D, the Unique Factorization Axiom can be formally expressed through precise mathematical notation and conditions.

The axiom states that every non-zero non-unit element x ∈ D can be expressed as:

x = p₁ × p₂ × ... × pₙ

where each pᵢ is a prime element in D. Furthermore, this representation is unique up to reordering and multiplication by units.

To formalize this more precisely:

1. Existence: For any non-zero non-unit x ∈ D, there exist primes p₁, p₂, ..., pₙ ∈ D such that x = p₁ × p₂ × ... × pₙ.

2. Uniqueness: If x = p₁ × p₂ × ... × pₙ = q₁ × q₂ × ... × qₘ where the pᵢ and qⱼ are primes, then n = m and there exists a permutation σ of {1, 2, ..., n} such that pᵢ and qσ(i) are associates (differ by a unit) for each i.

This formalization captures both the existence and uniqueness aspects of the axiom. The existence part ensures that every non-trivial element can be decomposed into primes, while the uniqueness part ensures that this decomposition is essentially unique.

In the context of abstract algebra, a UFD is specifically defined as an integral domain in which every non-zero non-unit element can be written as a product of irreducible elements in an essentially unique way. The UOR framework extends this mathematical concept to arbitrary domains with a composition operation, maintaining the core properties of existence and uniqueness in prime decomposition.

The mathematical rigor of this formalization provides a solid foundation for the subsequent axioms and ensures that the prime coordinate representation developed in the UOR framework has well-defined mathematical properties.
mathExpression: \text{If } x = p_1 \times p_2 \times \ldots \times p_n = q_1 \times q_2 \times \ldots \times q_m \text{ then } n = m \text{ and } \exists \sigma : \{1,2,\ldots,n\} \to \{1,2,\ldots,n\} \text{ s.t. } p_i \sim q_{\sigma(i)}
